comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Lt Blair also features in an Australian War Memorial photograph of the officers of 11th Bn, AIF: www.awm.gov.au/collection/E01778/

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: There was an article in the Western Mail of 21 April 1938 referring to the publication of a history of the 11th Battalion AIF, asking potential subscribers to contact a R. W. Blair of 79 William Street, Perth; via Trove, the National Library of Australia's digitised newspaper collection: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/37846948

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Assuming that it is the same person, it appears that R. W. Blair was later Secretary of the 11th Battalion AIF Association, e.g. inviting members to attend the funeral of their former colleague Private Victor Charles (Joker) Speed at Karrakatta in 1933: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/32594769 See also: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/32946656

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Robert Walton Blair, born Fremantle, WA; enlisted Kalgoorie, WA, 7 March 1915, aged 19; next of kin Mary Ellen Blair (mother). Digitised papers available from the National Archives of Australia: recordsearch.naa.gov.au/NameSearch/Interface/ItemDetail.a... There is a lot of detail in the records, but we know from them that he embarked for Alexandria at Fremantle on the 25 May 1915. He then spent some time in Egypt and the Dardanelles, but was hospitalised in October 1915 due to illness (enteritis), bad enough to be sent to hospital in England. He returned to Egypt before heading on to France in early 1916, being appointed Lance Corporal on 23 June 1916. He was promoted 2nd Lieutenant on 19 May 1917, then Lieutenant on 19 August 1917. In July 1918, he was seconded to the Australian Flying Corps for training as a Flying Officer Pilot, being based in England with 6th Training Squadron. He returned in Australia in 1919.

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Links to further information (including the same photograph) at: anzacsonline.net.au/2012/11/blair-robert-walton/

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Awards information at: www.awm.gov.au/research/people/honours_and_awards/person/... He was unsuccessfully recommended for a Military Cross in June 1918, the application reading: In the operations against the enemy position at MONT DE MERRIS on the night 2nd/3rd June, 1918, Lieut. BLAIR, who was in charge of communications, did much towards the success of the operation. He followed the first wave of the attack and on the first objective being gained, established communication. On completion of his task, notwithstanding the heavy enemy artillery and machine gun fine, he went forward to the second objective and succeeded in establishing and maintaining communication. Throughout the operation he set a splendid example of bravery and devotion to duty. www.awm.gov.au/research/people/honours_and_awards/person/...

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: University of Adelaide, Primary Examination 1909 Robert Walton Blair, Ksloorlie State School. Passed English grammar, composition and dictation; arithmetic, and geography, English history, Algebra. The West Australian Monday 18 October 1909, p.7 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/26240109?searchTerm=blai... Major Robert Walton Blair, Group Commander, No. 2 Group, V.D.C., Bunbury, as a Justice of the Peace for the Forrest and Mitchell Magisterial Districts; Government Gazette of W.A. September 3, 1943, p.780 Australia, Electoral Rolls indicates that Robert Walton Blair moved from Fremantle to Curtin between 1943 and 1949. Australia Death Index indicates Robert Walton Blair (Father: Robert A) died in 1973. www.ancestry.com.au

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: His son served and died in the Australian Air Force in World War II. PLTOFF BLAIR, ROBERT ALEXANDER WALTON Service No 415498 Unit 77 Squadron, RAF Date of Death Saturday, June 17, 1944 CWGC Info SON OF ROBERT WALTON BLAIR AND VERA MARION BLAIR, OF WEST LEEDERVILLE, WESTERN AUSTRALIA. Memorial RUNNYMEDE MEMORIAL Panel Panel 258. www.raafdb.com/view_casualty.asp?id=542 An interesting question as to the identity of an Aussie airman in Amsterdam (New Eastern) Cemetery - surmising it's one of 15 men including Blair, R A W Captain (Pilot) in a Halifax: RAAF PERSONNEL SERVING ON ATTACHMENT IN ROYAL AIR FORCE SQUADRONS AND SUPPORT UNITS IN WORLD WAR 2 AND MISSING WITH NO KNOWN GRAVE. 423597 Flight Sergeant ARMSTRONG, Gordon Arthur Source: AWM 237 (65) NAA : A705, 166/33/18 Commonwealth War Graves records W R Chorley : RAF Bomber Command Losses of the Second World War, Page 284, Volume 1944. Aircraft Type: Halifax Serial number: NA 508 Radio call sign: KN – A Unit: ATTD 77 SQN RAF Summary: Halifax NA508 took off from RAF Full Sutton, Yorkshire at 2315 hours on the night of 16/17th June1944, detailed to bomb Sterkrade, Germany. Nothing was heard from the aircraft after take off and it failed to return to base. Crew: RAAF 415498 PO Blair, R A W Captain (Pilot) RAF Sgt H L Moore (Flight Engineer) RAAF 425210 PO Pratt, L G (Observer) RAAF 423597 Flt Sgt G A Armstrong, (Air Bomber) RAAF 410370 WO J P O’Meara, (Wireless Air Gunner) RAAF 427807 FO Date, J M (Mid Upper Gunner) RAF Sgt D G Tastin, (Tail Gunner) A 1947 report by a Missing Research & Enquiry team stated “ the Communal Police at Neuwer-Amstel reported that the aircraft crashed in flames at Neuwer-Amstel on the night of 16/17 June 1944. German documents confirmed that only one body was recovered that of WO O’Meara.” He is buried at the Bergen-Op-Zoom War Cemetery, Locality Noord-Brabant, Netherlands. The other six crew members have no known grave and their names are commemorated on the Memorial to the Missing, Runnymede, Surrey, UK.. ww2talk.com/forums/topic/28134-netherlands-war-grave-phot...

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: The engagement is announced of Margaret Jean. elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. W. Blair of 24 Ruislip street. West Leederville, and Alfred William, elder son of Mr. and Mrs. A. R. Humphries. of 1045 Albany-road. Victoria Park. The West Australian Thursday 26 June 1947 p.14 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/46321448?searchTerm=blai...
